title: The Strengthening of Censorship
description: Fearing the contagious influence of the French Revolution, Pavel (Paul I of Russia) prohibited the importation of foreign books and the sending of young people abroad for education in 1800. At the Riga customs alone, 552 volumes intended for importation into Russia were confiscated. Esteemed authors such as Goethe, Schiller, Kant, Swift, and others fell into disfavor. All private ("free") printing houses in the country were closed. Pavel disapproved of the French fashion of clothing and words that reminded him of revolutionary France.

title: Assassination of Pavel I
description: A conspiracy was formed by Counts Peter Ludwig von der Pahlen, Nikita Petrovich Panin, and Admiral de Ribas, allegedly with the support of the British ambassador. On the night of March 23, 1801, a group of officers, including General Bennigsen and General Yashvil, stormed into Paul's bedroom at Saint Michael's Castle. They found him hiding and attempted to force him to sign his abdication, but Paul resisted. Ultimately, he was struck with a sword by Nikolay Zubov and was strangled and trampled to death. Paul's son, Alexander, who was present in the palace at the time, had given consent to overthrow Paul but had not anticipated assassination as the means. Alexander succeeded his father without punishing the assassins, and the official cause of death was declared as apoplexy.

title: Invention of powdered milk
description: The first modern production process for dried milk was invented by the Russian doctor Osip Krichevsky in 1802. The first commercial production of dried milk was organized by the Russian chemist M. Dirchoff in 1832.

title: Alexander I established the Ministry of Internal Affairs
description: The first interior ministry in Russia was created by Tsar Alexander I on 28 March 1802 in the process of government reforms to replace the aging collegia of Peter the Great. The MVD was one of the most powerful governmental bodies of the Empire, responsible for the police forces and Internal Guards and the supervision of gubernial administrations.

title: Invention of arc welding
description: In 1802, Petrov discovered the electric arc effect, thanks to his building the world's largest and most powerful Voltaic pile at the time. In "News of Galvanic-Voltaic Experiments", 1803, Petrov described experiments performed using the voltaic pile, detailing the stable arc discharge and the indication of its possible use in artificial lighting, melting metals for smelting and welding, obtaining pure metallic oxides, and reduction of metals from oxides mixed with powdered carbon and oils. It was not until the late 1880s that technology based on Petrov's experiments was developed with the goal of industrial usage.

title: Decree on free cultivators
description: Under this decree, the landlords received the right to give their serfs personal freedom and transfer land plots to them. The terms of release were determined by the landowner himself: free of charge, for a ransom, or on the terms of working out duties. During the reign of Alexander I, about 40,000 peasants received freedom in accordance with the decree.

title: Russo-Persian War (1804–1813)
description: The Russo-Persian War of 1804–1813 was one of the many wars between the Persian Empire and Imperial Russia, and began like many of their wars as a territorial dispute. The new Persian king, Fath Ali Shah Qajar, wanted to consolidate the northernmost reaches of his kingdom—modern-day Georgia—which had been annexed by Tsar Paul I several years after the Russo-Persian War of 1796. Like his Persian counterpart, the Tsar Alexander I was also new to the throne and equally determined to control the disputed territories. The war ended in 1813 with the Treaty of Gulistan which ceded the previously disputed territory of Georgia to Imperial Russia, and also the Iranian territories of Dagestan, most of what is nowadays Azerbaijan, and minor parts of Armenia.

title: War of the Third Coalition (1805–1806)
description: War of the Third Coalition was a European conflict spanning 1805 to 1806. During the war, France and its client states under Napoleon I opposed an alliance, the Third Coalition, which was made up of the United Kingdom, the Holy Roman Empire, the Russian Empire, Naples, Sicily, and Sweden. The Third Coalition itself came to full fruition in 1804–05 as Napoleon's actions in Italy and Germany spurred Austria and Russia into joining Britain against France.

title: Battle of Austerlitz
description: The Battle of Austerlitz (2 December 1805) also known as the Battle of the Three Emperors, was one of the most important and decisive engagements of the Napoleonic Wars. The battle occurred near the town of Austerlitz in the Austrian Empire. The decisive victory of Napoleon's Grande Armée at Austerlitz brought the War of the Third Coalition to a rapid end, with the Treaty of Pressburg signed by the Austrians later in the month.

title: Russo-Turkish War (1806–1812)
description: The Russo-Turkish War (1806–1812) between the Russian Empire and the Ottoman Empire was one of the Russo-Ottoman Wars. Russia prevailed, but both sides wanted peace as they feared Napoleon's moves to the east.

title: Treaties of Tilsit
description: The Treaties of Tilsit were two agreements signed in July 1807 after Napoleon's victory at Friedland. The first treaty was signed between Napoleon and Russian Emperor Alexander on July 7, while the second was signed with Prussia on July 9. These treaties had significant consequences for King Frederick William III of Prussia, who had already agreed to a truce after his defeat by the French. In Tilsit, he had to cede about half of his pre-war territories, which Napoleon used to create French sister republics and award to existing French client states and Russia. These treaties solidified Napoleon's control over Central Europe and secured alliances with Russia and Prussia against their common enemies, the United Kingdom and Sweden. As a result, it triggered the Anglo-Russian and Finnish wars.

title: Finnish War
description: The Finnish War was fought between the Kingdom of Sweden and the Russian Empire from 21 February 1808 to 17 September 1809 as part of the Napoleonic Wars. As a result of the war, the eastern third of Sweden was established as the autonomous Grand Duchy of Finland within the Russian Empire.

title: Treaty of Fredrikshamn
description: The Treaty of Fredrikshamn was a peace treaty concluded between Sweden and Imperial Russia on 17 September 1809. The treaty concluded the Finnish War and was signed in the Finnish town of Hamina (Swedish: Fredrikshamn). In the treaty, Sweden ceded Finnish territories to Russia.

title: Establishment of State Council
description: The State Council was established by Alexander I of Russia in 1810 as part of Speransky's reforms. Although envisaged by Speransky as the upper chamber of the Russian parliament, it was actually an advisory legislative body composed of people whom the tsar could trust. The number of members varied at different periods. Upon its establishment in 1810 there were 35 members; in 1890 there were 60. The main duty of the Council was the preliminary investigation, promulgation and abrogation of laws.

title: Surrender of the Turks at in Romania
description: During the Russo-Turkish War of 1806-1812, Russian forces under the command of General Mikhail Kutuzov defeated the Turkish army of Grand Vizier Ahmed Pasha near the settlement of Slobozia on the left bank of the Danube in Romania.

title: Treaty of Bucharest
description: The Treaty of Bucharest between the Ottoman Empire and the Russian Empire was signed on 28 May 1812 in Bucharest, and ratified on 5 July 1812, at the end of the Russo-Turkish War of 1806–1812. Under its terms, historical region of Bessarabia was ceded by the Ottoman Empire to Russia.  In Transcaucasia, the Ottomans renounced their claims to most of western Georgia by accepting the Russian annexation of the Kingdom of Imereti in 1810. Furthermore a truce was signed (Article 8 of the Treaty) with the rebelling Serbs and autonomy given to Serbia. The Treaty of Bucharest, signed by the Russian commander Mikhail Kutuzov, was ratified by Alexander I of Russia 13 days before Napoleon's invasion of Russia.

title: Patriotic War of 1812
description: The French invasion of Russia in 1812 was a military campaign led by Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte to conquer Russia. With an army of over 600,000 soldiers, Napoleon launched his offensive in June 1812, aiming to bring Russia under his control. However, the Russian forces, led by General Mikhail Kutuzov, adopted a strategy of retreating and employing scorched-earth tactics, denying the French army the resources and supplies they needed. As the harsh Russian winter set in, coupled with guerrilla attacks and the devastating Battle of Borodino, the French army suffered heavy casualties and was forced to retreat. The retreat turned into a disastrous rout, and by the end of the campaign, only a fraction of the original French army remained. The French invasion of Russia proved to be a significant turning point in the Napoleonic Wars and marked a major setback for Napoleon's empire.

title: Treaty of Gulistan
description: The Treaty of Gulistan was a peace treaty concluded between the Russian Empire and Iran on 24 October 1813 as a result of the first full-scale Russo-Persian War (1804 to 1813). The treaty confirmed the ceding and inclusion of what is now Dagestan, eastern Georgia, most of the Republic of Azerbaijan and parts of northern Armenia from Iran into the Russian Empire.

title: Battle of Paris
description: The Battle of Paris was fought on 30–31 March 1814 between the Sixth Coalition, consisting of Russia, Austria, and Prussia, and the French Empire. After a day of fighting in the suburbs of Paris, the French surrendered on March 31, ending the War of the Sixth Coalition and forcing Emperor Napoleon to abdicate and go into exile.

title: Congress of Vienna
description: The Congress of Vienna in 1815 was a diplomatic conference that aimed to redraw the political map of Europe following the Napoleonic Wars. The major European powers, including Austria, Russia, Prussia, and Great Britain, convened to negotiate a comprehensive settlement to restore stability and maintain a balance of power. Led by key statesmen such as Prince Klemens von Metternich of Austria, the congress sought to address territorial boundaries, political systems, and the restoration of monarchies. The principles of legitimacy, conservatism, and compensation were emphasized during the negotiations. The final agreements resulted in significant territorial adjustments, the restoration of Bourbon monarchy in France, the establishment of the German Confederation, and the commitment to maintain the status quo. The Congress of Vienna laid the foundation for a new era of peace and stability in Europe that lasted for several decades.

title: Foundation of Union of Salvation
description: The Union of Salvation was the first secret political society of the Decembrists, participants of the Russian anti-government armed movement, who organized the uprising on Senate Square in St. Petersburg in December of 1825.

title: Abolishing of serfdom (salvery) in Baltic regions of Russia 1816-1819
description: Serfdom was abolished in the Baltic regions of the Russian Empire (present-day Estonia and Latvia).

title: Caucasian War
description: The Caucasian War was a 19th century military conflict between the Russian Empire and various peoples of the North Caucasus who resisted subjugation during the Russian conquest of the Caucasus. It consisted of a series of military actions waged by the Russian Imperial Army and Cossack settlers against the native inhabitants such as the Adyghe, Abaza–Abkhaz, Ubykhs, Chechens, and Dagestanis as the Tsars sought to expand. The conflict officially lasted from 1817 until 1864.

title: Foundation of Welfare Union
description: The Welfare Union was formed on the bases of the Union of Salvation in 1818 and consisted of Decembrists, participants of the Russian anti-government armed movement, who organized the uprising on Senate Square in St. Petersburg in December of 1825.

title: Discovery of Antarctica (First Russian Antarctic Expedition)
description: The First Russian Antarctic Expedition took place in 1819–1821 under the direction of Fabian Bellingshausen and Mikhail Lazarev. The expedition aimed to reach the Southern Ocean in order to prove or disprove the existence of a suspected seventh continent, Antarctica. The sloop Vostok was under the command of Bellingshausen, while Lazarev commanded the sloop Mirny. Overall, the crew consisted of 190 people.

title: Invention of monorail
description: The first monorail prototype was made in Russia in 1820 by Ivan Elmanov. Attempts at creating monorail alternatives to conventional railways have been made since the early part of the 19th century. Elmanov’s monorail prototype, called The Road on Poles, was a carriage pulled by horses along wooden beams mounted on poles.

title: Congress of Laibach
description: The Congress of Laibach was a conference of the members of the Holy Alliance (including Russia), held in 1821 as part of the Congress System which was the decided attempt of the five Great Powers to settle international problems after the Napoleonic Wars through discussion and collective weight rather than on the battlefield. A result of the Congress was the authorization of Austrian intervention in the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies in order to quell a liberal uprising.

title: Rescript for the Prohibition of Secret Societies
description: The ban on Masonic lodges in Russia in the early 19th century was a response to their increasing influence and potential threat to the state. Freemasonry had flourished in Russia since the appointment of John Philips as provincial Grand Master in 1731. The Grand Lodge of Astraea, established in 1815, became an independent fraternal organization recognized by other European Grand Lodges. However, as Masonic activities shifted towards politics and the state struggled to supervise them, authorities grew concerned. Similar bans had been imposed in other European countries. The formation of military camp lodges within Masonic circles, particularly involving young officers, raised alarm as they became influential political and secret military organizations, eventually playing a role in the Decembrist movement. Emperor Alexander I initially tolerated Masonic activity, but as their influence grew, he imposed restrictions to maintain control over parallel power structures.

title: Establishment of Society of United Slavs
description: The Society of United Slavs was a secret anti-state pan-Slavic organization of the Decembrists, participants of the Russian anti-government armed movement, who organized the uprising on Senate Square in St. Petersburg in December of 1825.

title: Russo-American Treaty of 1824
description: The Russo-American Treaty of 1824 (also known as the Convention of 1824) was signed in St. Petersburg between representatives of Russia and the United States on April 17, 1824. The accord contained six articles. It gave Russian claims on the Pacific Northwest coast of North America south of parallel 54°40′ north (over what Americans had known as the Oregon Country) to the United States.

title: Death of Alexander I
description: With his mental health deteriorating, Alexander grew increasingly suspicious of those around him, more withdrawn, more religious, and more passive. In the autumn of 1825 the Emperor undertook a voyage to the south of Russia due to the increasing illness of his wife. During his trip he himself caught typhus, from which he died in the southern city of Taganrog on 19 November 1825. However, his death wouldn't fully be known until December, due to Taganrog being far from the capital or any other large city. His two brothers disputed who would become tsar—each wanted the other to do so. There are many rumours and legends, of which the most often told claimed that he did not die but rather became a Siberian hermit named Feodor Kuzmich. Historians reject the legends, but popular writers resurrect them often.

title: Decembrist Revolt
description: The Decembrist Revolt took place in Russia on 26 December 1825, following the sudden death of Emperor Alexander I. Alexander's heir-presumptive, Konstantin, had privately declined the succession, unknown to the court, and his younger brother Nicholas ascended the throne as Emperor Nicholas I. While some of the army had sworn loyalty to Nicholas, a force of about 3,000 troops tried to mount a military coup in favour of Konstantin. The rebels, although weakened by dissension between their leaders, confronted the loyalists outside the Senate building in the presence of a large crowd. In the confusion, the Emperor's envoy, Mikhail Miloradovich, was assassinated. Eventually, the loyalists opened fire with heavy artillery, which scattered the rebels. Many were sentenced to hanging, prison, or exile to Siberia. The conspirators became known as the Decembrists.

title: Russo-Persian War (1826–1828)
description: Persia began hostilities in the hope of revisiting the results of the war of 1804–1813. At first, the small Russian troops were forced to retreat, but in September 1826 a turning point came. The Russians launched a counteroffensive, took Erivan, Tabriz, and in January 1828 opened their way to Tehran. The war ended with the signing of the Turkmanchay peace treaty, according to which Persia confirmed all the conditions of the Gulistan peace of 1813, recognized the transfer of the Erivan and Nakhichevan khanates to Russia and paid Russia a large indemnity.

title: Treaty of London (1827)
description: The Treaty of London was signed on the 6 July 1827 by Great Britain, France and Russia. The three main European powers had called upon Greece and the Ottoman Empire to cease hostilities that had been going on since the Greeks revolted against the Ottoman rule on 17 March 1821. After years of negotiation, the European allied powers had finally decided to intervene in the war on the side of the Greeks.

title: Russo-Turkish War (1828–1829)
description: The Russo-Turkish War of 1828–1829 was sparked by the Greek War of Independence of 1821–1829. War broke out after the Ottoman Sultan Mahmud II closed the Dardanelles to Russian ships and revoked the 1826 Akkerman Convention in retaliation for Russian participation in October 1827 in the Battle of Navarino. As a result of the war, the Treaty of Adrianople was signed, ceding the eastern shore of the Black Sea and the mouth of the Danube to the Russians.

title: Discovery of non-Euclidean geometry
description: The discovery of non-Euclidean geometry took significant strides in the early 19th century. Carl Friedrich Gauss and Ferdinand Karl Schweikart independently developed ideas of non-Euclidean geometry around 1813 and 1818 respectively, but did not publish their findings. However, in 1829-1830, the Russian mathematician Nikolai Ivanovich Lobachevsky and in 1832, the Hungarian mathematician János Bolyai separately published treatises on hyperbolic geometry. Lobachevsky and Bolyai are considered the foundational figures of non-Euclidean geometry, with hyperbolic geometry often referred to as Lobachevskian or Bolyai-Lobachevskian geometry.

title: November Uprising
description: The November Uprising (1830–31) was an armed rebellion in the heartland of partitioned Poland against the Russian Empire. The uprising began on 29 November 1830 in Warsaw when young Polish officers from the military academy of the Army of Congress Poland revolted, led by Lieutenant Piotr Wysocki. Large segments of the peoples of Lithuania, Belarus, and Right-bank Ukraine soon joined the uprising. Although the insurgents achieved local successes, a numerically superior Imperial Russian Army under Ivan Paskevich eventually crushed the uprising.

title: Battle of Warsaw (1831)
description: The Battle of Warsaw was fought in September 1831 between Imperial Russia and Poland. After a two-day assault on the city's western fortifications, the Polish defenses collapsed and the city was evacuated. It was the largest battle and the final episode of the Polish–Russian War of 1830–31, a conflict that became better known as the November Uprising.

title: The Digest of Laws of the Russian Empire is published
description: The Digest of Laws of the Russian Empire is the official publication of the current legislative acts of the Russian Empire, arranged in thematic order, prepared by the Second Department under the leadership of M. M. Speransky at the beginning of the Nikolaev era and reprinted in whole or in part until the October Revolution of 1918. It consisted of fifteen volumes, including, among other things, fundamental laws , legislation on provincial institutions , state finances , state rights , acts in the regional administrative law , civil and criminal laws , as well as indexes, supporting materials and other reference apparatus.

title: Sale of serfs at auctions prohibited
description: The year saw prohibition of sale of serfs at public auctions.

title: Treaty of Hünkâr İskelesi
description: The Treaty of Hünkâr İskelesi was a treaty signed between the Russian Empire and the Ottoman Empire on July 8, 1833, following the military aid of Russia against Mehmed Ali that same year. The treaty brought about an alliance between the two powers, as well as a guarantee that the Ottomans would close the Dardanelles to any foreign warships if the Russians requested such action.

title: Caucasian Imamate under Imam Shamil’s leadership in 1834-1859
description: Imam Shamil ruled the Caucasian Imamate from 1834 to 1859, making him the most prominent leader in its history. He aimed to unite and strengthen the Muslim tribes of the region. Despite seeking British support during the "Great Game," no official assistance was received. Shamil successfully conquered the Western Muslim tribes, transforming fragmented villages into a unified country. However, this came at a great cost, with significant casualties suffered, such as in the Siege of Akhoulgo in 1839. In 1859, Emperor Alexander II of Russia offered Shamil a peaceful surrender, signaling the end of the Caucasian Imamate. Nonetheless, fighting in the region continued even after Shamil's surrender.

title: Statute on Jews of 1835
description: In 1835, a new "Statute on Jews" was approved by the Emperor. According to this law, Jews in Belarus were only permitted to reside in cities, while in Malorissiya they were allowed to live everywhere except in Kiev and villages owned by the state treasury. In Novorossiya, Jews could reside in all settlements except for Nikolaev and Sevastopol. In the Baltic provinces, only native-born Jews were allowed to live. Jews were prohibited from resettling in a 50-verst border zone. In the internal provinces, Jews were allowed to stay for no more than six weeks with passports issued by governors, on the condition of wearing Russian clothing.

title: Chaadaev’s Letters published
description: Chaadaev's Letters were a series of philosophical and critical essays written by Russian philosopher and intellectual, Pyotr Chaadaev, in the 19th century. In these letters, Chaadaev expressed his deep dissatisfaction with the state of Russian society, culture, and intellectual development. He harshly criticized Russia's historical trajectory, its adherence to autocracy, and its isolation from Western intellectual and cultural movements. Chaadaev argued that Russia had failed to contribute meaningfully to human progress and had been left behind by more advanced Western societies. The publication of Chaadaev's Letters in 1836 caused a considerable uproar and led to his being declared insane by the authorities, subsequently leading to his confinement in a mental institution for the remainder of his life. Despite this, Chaadaev's Letters had a profound impact on subsequent generations of Russian intellectuals and played a significant role in shaping the course of Russian philosophical and cultural thought.

title: 1st railroad in Russia
description: In the early 1830s Russian inventors father and son Cherepanovs built the first Russian steam locomotive. The first railway line was built in Russia in 1837 between Saint-Petersburg and Tsarskoye Selo, and called the Tsarskoye Selo Railway. It was 27 km long and linked the Imperial Palaces at Tsarskoye Selo and Pavlovsk. Track gauge was 6 feet (1830 mm). This railway has been described as a "toy" railway, as it had no economic, political or social impact on the Russian Empire.

title: Ministry of State Property founded
description: The Ministry of State Property (opened in 1837-1838) was the ministry in the government of the Russian Empire which controlled government-owned lands and any other government property, especially farms and agricultural land, and prior to the abolition of serfdom, the government peasants that worked the lands. In each province, Chambers of State Property were formed, and peasant self-government was introduced in the countryside. The poll tax was replaced by a land tax. Hospitals, schools, churches began to be built in the villages.

title: Siege of Akhoulgo (Caucasian war)
description: In 1839, Shamil, along with approximately 4,000 of his followers, faced a siege in their mountain stronghold of Akhoulgo in the Caucasus region. The Russian army, led by General Pavel Grabbe, faced challenges due to the difficult terrain and lack of supplies caused by Shamil's scorched-earth tactics. After negotiations failed, the Russian army attacked the stronghold, and after two days of fighting, they were successful in securing it. However, Shamil managed to escape during the first night of the attack. Despite this setback, Shamil regrouped in Chechnya and quickly gained influence over the local clans, while many Dagestani and Chechen chieftains pledged loyalty to the Tsar.

title: Convention of London (1840)
description: The Convention of London of 1840 was a treaty with the title of Convention for the Pacification of the Levant, signed on 15 July 1840 between the Great Powers of United Kingdom, Austria, Prussia, Russia on one hand and the Ottoman Empire on the other. The Convention lent some support to the Ottoman Empire, which was having difficulties with its Egyptian possessions.

title: Ban of sale of serfs
description: Russian nobles banned from selling serfs.

title: Decree on obliged peasants
description: “Obliged peasants" were former serfs in Russia who transitioned into contractual relations with landowners based on the decree of April 2 (14), 1842. The decree was the result of the work of a secret committee established on November 10, 1839, to determine the conditions for the emancipation of peasants, independent of the decree on free agricultural laborers. According to the agreement between landowners and peasants, approved by the government, the peasants gained personal freedom. Landowners retained the right to estate police. The land remained in the ownership of the landowner, who provided the peasants with a plot of land in exchange for a "proportional" rent or labor services. There were no limitations on the authority of landowners. It was not obligatory for landowners to enter into such agreements.

title: Shamil regains Dagestan
description: In 1843, Shamil, the leader of the resistance in the Caucasus, managed to regain control of Dagestan. He had built a strong army of mounted warriors known as murtazeks. Accompanied by his personal executioner, he exerted pressure on the non-combatants caught between the opposing sides. Shamil coordinated a strategic movement with his allies, reaching Untsukul with a united force of 10,000 men, catching the Russians off guard. Local Russian garrisons rushed to respond but suffered heavy losses, while Shamil held every Russian fort in the region except the capital. Despite the Russians' attempts to reinforce their positions, Shamil tactically withdrew to Dylym.

title: Dagestan stabilized
description: In late 1843, Tsar Nicholas ordered Neidhardt to disperse Shamil's forces and establish Russian control over the mountains. A significant military force consisting of 26 battalions and four Cossack regiments was sent for this purpose. The murid fighters were pushed back from the Caspian coast, and several victories were achieved by the Russian forces. Passek emerged triumphant at Gilli, defeating a large murid force, while Argutinsky secured a victory on the upper Samur River. Shamil suffered defeats at Akusha, and an attack on Tilitl failed. Shamil's brutal actions, including a massacre in the village of Tsonteri, intensified the conflict. Additionally, Daniel Beg, the Sultan of Elisu, revolted against Russian attempts to limit his power, leading to further unrest in southern Dagestan. Although progress was made in fortifying Vozdvizhenskoye on the Argun River, by the year's end, the frontiers were stabilized without significant overall achievements.

title: Establishment of Russian Geographical Society
description: The Russian Geographical Society, founded in August of 1845, is a learned society based in Saint Petersburg, Russia. It promotes geography, exploration and nature protection with research programs in fields including oceanography[citation needed], ethnography, ecology and statistics.

title: Invention of oil well drilling
description: In 1846, Baku (settlement Bibi-Heybat) the first ever well was drilled with percussion tools to a depth of 21 metres (69 ft) for oil exploration. In 1846–1848, the first modern oil wells were drilled on the Absheron Peninsula north-east of Baku, by Russian engineer Vasily Semyonov considering the ideas of Nikolay Voskoboynikov.

title: Regulation on the Governance of the Kalmyk People
description: On April 23, 1847, Nicholas I signed a new "Regulation on the Governance of the Kalmyk People," according to which Kalmykia remained within the framework of the Ministry of State Property, and the Kalmyks became full-fledged subjects of the Russian state. Religious freedom was granted, allowing for the conversion of religion. Kalmyks who embraced Orthodoxy acquired the status of state peasants.

title: French revolution of 1848
description: On March 26, 1848, Emperor Nicholas I issued a manifesto in response to the February Revolution in Paris and the revolutionary uprising in Vienna, asserting that Russia remains unaffected by revolutionary influences. The revolution in France and the spread of unrest in neighboring countries troubled Nicholas, leading him to sever diplomatic relations with France. In his manifesto, Nicholas vowed to defend Russia's honor and borders, invoking the example of Orthodox ancestors and proclaiming, "With us is God, understand, you nations, and submit, for God is with us."

title: Russian Intervention and the Hungarian Revolution of 1848
description: In early July 1849, the Russian army under the command of Field Marshal I.F. Paskevich entered the territory of Hungary to help the Austrian Empire suppress the Hungarian Revolution of 1848-1849. In the autumn, having fully fulfilled their allied obligations, the Russian troops left Hungary.

title: Unsanctioned founding of Nikolaevsk, first Russian settlement in Amur River’s mouth
description: In 1849, Nevelskoy journeyed to the capital after handing over the ship "Baikal" in Okhotsk. His proposal to establish a settlement at the Amur River mouth in 1850 was unsupported, but he was assigned to establish a wintering site in the Bay of Happiness. Nevelskoy founded Petrovskoye Wintering there and, defying orders, also established the Nikolayevsk Post at the Amur River mouth. Emperor Nicholas I praised his actions as patriotic and awarded him the Order of St. Vladimir, event though initially government circles expressed dissatisfaction.

title: Railroad connecting St.Petersburg with Moscow
description: The first railroad between St. Petersburg and Moscow, known as the Moscow-St. Petersburg Railway, was opened in 1851. It was a significant milestone in Russian transportation history and played a crucial role in connecting the two major cities, promoting trade, and facilitating travel and communication between them.

title: Admiral Putyatin’s mission to Japan
description: In 1852, the Imperial Russian government decided to establish diplomatic relations with Japan. Grand Duke Konstantin Nikolayevich supported Admiral Putyatin's plan to strengthen Russia's position in the Pacific Ocean. The urgency to organize the expedition arose from the fact that an American squadron led by Matthew Perry was preparing to negotiate a trade agreement with Japan. The country that would break Japan's long-standing policy of isolation, known as sakoku, would secure the most favorable trading conditions.

title: Crimean War
description: The Crimean War took place from 1853 to 1856 and involved multiple countries and alliances. It was primarily fought between the Russian Empire on one side and an alliance of the Ottoman Empire, France, Britain, and Sardinia on the other. The war was triggered by a dispute over religious rights in the Holy Land and the protection of Christian minorities in the Ottoman Empire. It quickly escalated into a broader conflict that encompassed battles on the Crimean Peninsula, the Black Sea, and the Caucasus region. The war saw significant military advancements, including the use of railways, telegraphs, and modern weaponry. The conflict ended with the Treaty of Paris in 1856, which confirmed the integrity of the Ottoman Empire and led to territorial adjustments and diplomatic changes in Europe. The Crimean War had far-reaching consequences, such as weakening the Russian Empire, contributing to the decline of the Ottoman Empire, and setting the stage for future conflicts in Europe.

title: UK and France join Crimean War, Austria threatens
description: Nicholas felt that because of Russian assistance in suppressing the Hungarian revolution of 1848, Austria would side with him or at the very least remain neutral. Austria, however, felt threatened by the Russian troops in the Balkans. On 27 February 1854, the United Kingdom and France demanded the withdrawal of Russian forces from the principalities. Austria supported them and, without declaring war on Russia, refused to guarantee its neutrality. Russia's rejection of the ultimatum proved to be the justification used by Britain and France to enter the war.

title: Kingdom of Sardinia joins Crimean War
description: By 1855, the Italian Kingdom of Sardinia sent an expeditionary force to Crimea sided with France, Britain and the Ottoman Empire. The front settled into the siege of Sevastopol, involving brutal conditions for troops on both sides.

title: Death of Nicholas I
description: Nicholas died on 2 March 1855, during the Crimean War, at the Winter Palace in St. Petersburg. He caught a chill, refused medical treatment and died of pneumonia, although there were rumors he was committing a passive suicide by refusing treatment. He reigned for 30 years, and was succeeded by his son Alexander II.

title: Treaty of Paris (1856)
description: The Treaty of Paris of 1856 brought an end to the Crimean War between the Russian Empire and an alliance of the Ottoman Empire, the United Kingdom, the Second French Empire and the Kingdom of Sardinia. The treaty, signed on 30 March 1856 at the Congress of Paris, made the Black Sea neutral territory, closing it to all warships and prohibiting fortifications and the presence of armaments on its shores. The treaty diminished Russian influence in the region. Conditions for the return of Sevastopol and other towns and cities in the south of Crimea to Russia were severe since no naval or military arsenal could be established by Russia on the coast of the Black Sea.

title: Abolishing of military settlements
description: Military settlements represented a special organization of the Russian military forces in 1810–1857, which allowed the combination of military service and agricultural employment.

title: Treaty of Aigun
description: The Treaty of Aigun was an 1858 treaty between the Russian Empire and the Qing dynasty that established much of the modern border between the Russian Far East and China. Negotiations began after China was threatened with war on a second front by Governor-General of the Far East Nikolay Muraviev when China was suppressing the Taiping Rebellion. Russia received over 600,000 square kilometers (231,660 sq mi) of Outer Manchuria.

title: 1859–1864 - the end of the Caucasian war
description: The Caucasian war is called the actions of Russian troops in the North Caucasus during the annexation of the region to the Russian Empire. The period of the Caucasian War from 1834 to 1859, when Imam Shamil was the leader of the highlanders, is considered the most intense. In 1859, during the assault on the village of Gunib, Shamil surrendered, after which the resistance of the highlanders began to decline. In 1864, with the capture of the Kbaada tract, the war ended.

title: Convention of Peking
description: Beijing Treaty between the Russian Empire and the Qing Empire. The agreement confirmed the Russian-Chinese border along the Amur River, determined by the Aigun Treaty. The border from the confluence of the Ussuri into the Amur was drawn in such a way that the Ussuri Territory departed to Russia. Residents of border areas were allowed free barter. Russian merchants in China and Chinese in Russia received "special protection from both governments.”

title: Invention of Russian salad (Olivier)
description: Olivier salad is a traditional salad dish in Russian cuisine, which is also popular in other post-Soviet countries and around the world. The original version of the salad was invented in the 1860s in Russia by a cook of Belgian origin, Lucien Olivier, the chef of the Hermitage, one of Moscow's most celebrated restaurants. Olivier's salad quickly became immensely popular, and became the restaurant's signature dish.

title: Emancipation reform of 1861
description: The emancipation reform of 1861 in Russia was the first and most important of the liberal reforms enacted during the reign (1855–1881) of Emperor Alexander II of Russia. The reform effectively abolished serfdom throughout the Russian Empire.

title: Military reforms of Alexander II
description: Military reforms of Alexander II - a series of transformations in the military sphere in 1856-1874. The bulk of the reforms were carried out starting in 1862 and ended with the introduction of universal military service in 1874. The most important author of military reforms, who led their implementation, was the Minister of War D. A. Milyutin , which is why they are often called “Milyutin reforms”.

title: January Uprising (Poland uprising)
description: The January Uprising was an insurrection principally in Russia's Kingdom of Poland that was aimed at the restoration of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth. It began on 22 January 1863 and continued until the last insurgents were captured by the Russian forces in 1864. It was the longest-lasting insurgency in partitioned Poland. The conflict engaged all levels of society and arguably had profound repercussions on contemporary international relations and ultimately provoked a social and ideological paradigm shift in national events that went on to have a decisive influence on the subsequent development of Polish society.

title: Invention of icebreaker ship
description: The Russian ship Pilot of 1864 played a significant role as a precursor to modern icebreakers equipped with propellers. It possessed a sturdy metal hull and a distinctive rounded shape. It was commissioned by the renowned merchant and shipbuilder, Mikhail Britnev. One of the notable modifications made to the vessel was altering its bow to enhance its ice-clearing capabilities. With a 20° raise from the keel line, the Pilot could effectively push itself atop the ice and break through it. Britnev drew inspiration for the design of the ship's bow from the traditional Pomor boats that had successfully navigated the icy waters of the White Sea and Barents Sea for centuries.

title: Judicial reform of Alexander II
description: The judicial reform of Alexander II is generally considered one of the most successful and consistent of all his reforms (along with the military reform). A completely new court system and order of legal proceedings were established. The reform included the establishment of the principle of equality of the parties involved, the introduction of public hearings, the jury trial, and the institution of professional advocacy that had never existed in Russia.

title: 1865-1873: Russia incorporates Central Asian states
description: The incorporation of Central Asian states, including the Khanate of Khiva, the Khanate of Kokand, and the Emirate of Bukhara, into the Russian Empire. In the 19th century, Russia expanded its influence and control over these territories through a series of military campaigns and diplomatic maneuvers.

title: Assassination attempt on Alexander II
description: Alexander maintained a generally liberal course. Radicals complained he did not go far enough, and he became a target for numerous assassination plots, including one in 1866. The attempted assassination in 1866 started a more conservative period that lasted until his death. The Tsar made a series of new appointments, replacing liberal ministers with conservatives.

title: Sale of Alaska to USA
description: The Sale of Alaska was the United States' acquisition of Alaska from the Russian Empire. Alaska was formally transferred to the United States on October 18, 1867, through a treaty ratified by the United States Senate.

title: Battle of Zerabulak
description: The battle on the Zerabulak heights is the decisive battle of the Russian army under the command of General Kaufman with the army of the Bukhara emir Muzaffar, which took place in June 1868, on the slopes of the Zera-tau mountain range, between Samarkand and Bukhara. It ended with the defeat of the Bukhara army, and the transition of the Bukhara Emirate to vassal dependence on the Russian Empire.

title: Invention of Periodic Table (Mendeleev)
description: Although other chemists had found some other versions of the periodic system at about the same time, Russian chemist Dmitri Mendeleev was the most dedicated to developing and defending his system, and it was his system that most impacted the scientific community. In 1869, Mendeleev began arranging the elements and comparing them by their atomic weights. He began with a few elements, and over the course of the day his system grew until it encompassed most of the known elements. After he found a consistent arrangement, his printed table appeared in May 1869 in the journal of the Russian Chemical Society.

title: Statute on cities’ self-governance
description: According to the statute, all-class elected bodies of city self-government were established. They were entrusted with the solution of administrative and economic issues: the improvement of the city, health care, public education, promoting the development of trade and industry, fighting fires. City dumas became administrative bodies of self-government, city councils became executive bodies.

title: The London Treaty of 1871
description: As per the London Treaty, Russia and Turkey were allowed to have any number of warships in the Black Sea. Keeping the ban on the passage of Russian warships through the straits, the participants of the conference introduced a clause allowing Turkey to pass through them warships of friendly countries. Nevertheless, the London Treaty was a diplomatic victory for Russia, forcing a revision of the terms of the Paris Peace, which limited its sovereignty in the Black Sea.

title: Krenholm strike
description: The Krenholm strike is a large strike of textile workers of the Krenholm manufactory in 1872 in the city of Narva of the Russian Empire .

title: League of the Three Emperors
description: On 22 October 1873, Bismarck negotiated an agreement between the monarchs of Austria-Hungary, Russia and Germany. The alliance sought to resurrect the Holy Alliance of 1815 and act as a bulwark against radical sentiments that the rulers found unsettling. It was preceded by the Schönbrunn Convention, signed by Russia and Austria–Hungary on 6 June 1873.

title: Going to the People
description: Going to the People was a populist movement in the Russian Empire. It was largely inspired by the work of Russian theorists such as Mikhail Bakunin and Pyotr Lavrov, who advocated that groups of dedicated revolutionaries could inspire a mass movement to overthrow the ruling class, especially as it concerned the peasantry. The anarchist Peter Kropotkin called the experience "the mad summer of 1874”.

title: Treaty of Saint Petersburg (1875)
description: The Treaty of Saint Petersburg between the Empire of Japan and the Russian Empire, signed on 7 May 1875, stipulated that Japan cedes to Russia the part of Sakhalin island it then owned in exchange for the group of the Kuril Islands owned by Russia (between Iturup island and the Kamchatka Peninsula). Consequently, Sakhalin island as a whole became Russian territory, and the entire Kuril archipelago Japanese territory.

title: Kokand Khanate annexed
description: In 1875, the rebels overthrew the Kokand Khan Khudoyar, who fled to Khojent. Trying to capture the former ruler, the Kokand detachments invaded the territory of the Turkestan Governor General. This led to a campaign of Russian troops against Kokand. In 1876, the territory of the Kokand Khanate became part of the Turkestan Governor General.

title: Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)
description: The Russo-Turkish War of 1877–1878 was a conflict between the Ottoman Empire and a coalition led by the Russian Empire, and including Bulgaria, Romania, Serbia, and Montenegro. Fought in the Balkans and in the Caucasus, it originated in emerging 19th century Balkan nationalism. Additional factors included the Russian goals of recovering territorial losses endured during the Crimean War of 1853–56, re-establishing itself in the Black Sea and supporting the political movement attempting to free Balkan nations from the Ottoman Empire. The Russian-led coalition won the war, pushing the Ottomans back all the way to the gates of Constantinople, leading to the intervention of the western European great powers.

title: Congress of Berlin
description: Under pressure from Great Britain and Austria, Russia agreed to revise the terms of the San Stefano peace at the Berlin Congress. Serbia, Romania and Montenegro retained their independence, but their territories were reduced in comparison with those determined by the Treaty of San Stefano. Only northern Bulgaria became an autonomous principality, Austria-Hungary occupied Bosnia and Herzegovina, England received Cyprus. Russia retained the mouth of the Danube, Ardagan and Kars, Bayazet returned to Turkey, Batum became a port free for trade.

title: People's Will terrorist group formed
description: Narodnaya Volya (lit. 'People's Will') was a late 19th-century revolutionary socialist political organization and left-wing terrorist group operating in the Russian Empire, which conducted assassinations of government officials in an attempt to overthrow the autocratic Tsarist system. Composed primarily of young revolutionary socialist intellectuals believing in the efficacy of terrorism, Narodnaya Volya emerged in Autumn 1879 from the split of an earlier revolutionary organization called Zemlya i Volya ("Land and Liberty”). This group was responsible for carrying out a successful assassination attempt on Alexander II in 1881.

title: Conquest of the Akhal-Teke oasis in Turkmenistan
description: The Akhal-Teke Expedition, also known as the Battle of Geok-Tepe, was a military campaign conducted by the Russian army to conquer the territories of the Tekke Turkmen people. It took place between 1880 and 1881 in the territory of present-day Turkmenistan.

title: Discovery of vitamins
description: In 1881, Russian medical doctor Nikolai I. Lunin studied the effects of scurvy at the University of Tartu. He fed mice an artificial mixture of all the separate constituents of milk known at that time, namely the proteins, fats, carbohydrates, and salts. The mice that received only the individual constituents died, while the mice fed by milk itself developed normally. He made a conclusion that "a natural food such as milk must therefore contain, besides these known principal ingredients, small quantities of unknown substances essential to life.” These elements were vitamins.

title: Assassination of Alexander II
description: During the years of his reign, the emperor survived several assassination attempts: in April 1866, in May 1867, in April and November 1879, in February 1880. The attempt, which became successful, was prepared by members of the Narodnaya Volya organization. The emperor was mortally wounded in a bomb explosion and died the same day in the Winter Palace. The attackers were arrested and executed.

title: Labor statute 1882
description: The statute of June 1, 1882, banned employment of children under the age of 12. For children aged 12-15, it limited their working hours to 8 hours per day (with no more than 4 consecutive hours) and prohibited night work (from 9 pm to 5 am) and work on Sundays. It also banned the use of child labor in hazardous industries. The owners of enterprises were required to "provide the opportunity" for children who did not have a certificate of completing at least one grade of elementary public school or an equivalent educational institution to attend school for at least 3 hours a day or 18 hours per week.

title: Emancipation of Labour Marxist group formed
description: Emancipation of Labour was the first Russian Marxist group. It was founded in exile by Georgi Plekhanov, Vasily Ignatov, Vera Zasulich, Leo Deutsch, and Pavel Axelrod, at Geneva (Switzerland) in 1883. The group published the first Russian language translations of many works by Karl Marx and distributed them. It became the major adversary to the Narodniks on the left wing of politics in the Russian Empire.

title: Catherine's railway
description: A railroad in Donetsk region of the Russian Empire, finished in 1884, spanning 523 km from Donetsk coal mines to Russia’s southern ports on the Black Sea.

title: Labor statute 1885
description: According to the statute titled "On Prohibition of Night Work for Minors and Women at Factories and Manufactures”, night work was prohibited for adolescents under 17 years of age and women in cotton, linen, and wool factories. It came into effect on October 1, 1885. The Minister of Finance had the authority to extend the law to other industries, but it was only applied to hazardous work in porcelain and match production. In 1897, the law was extended to cover all textile production, including enterprises in the flax industry and the processing of mixed fabrics.

title: Inauguration of Trans-Caspian railway
description: The Trans-Caspian Railway, completed in 1886, is a railway that follows the path of the Silk Road through much of western Central Asia. It was built by the Russian Empire during its expansion into Central Asia in the 19th century.

title: Reinsurance Treaty
description: The Reinsurance Treaty was a diplomatic agreement between the German Empire and the Russian Empire that was in effect from 1887 to 1890. Only a handful of top officials in Berlin and St. Petersburg knew of its existence since it was so secret. The treaty played a critical role in German Chancellor Otto von Bismarck's extremely complex and ingenious network of alliances and agreements, which aimed to keep the peace in Europe and to maintain Germany's economic, diplomatic and political dominance. It helped keep the peace for both Russia and Germany.

title: Borki train disaster
description: The Borki train disaster occurred on October 29, 1888 (N.S.), near Borki station in the former Kharkov Governorate of the Russian Empire (present-day Birky, Chuhuiv Raion, Kharkiv Oblast, Ukraine), 295 kilometers south of Kursk, when the imperial train carrying Tsar Alexander III of Russia and his family from Crimea to Saint Petersburg derailed at high speed. Twenty-one people died at the scene and two later, and many others were injured. According to the official version of events, Alexander held the collapsed roof of the royal car on his shoulders while his family escaped the crash site uninjured.

title: Creation of Ussuri Cossack Host
description: The Ussuri Cossack Host was created in 1889 on the basis of an unmounted half-battalion of the Amur Cossack Host and later reinforced with settlers from the Don Cossack Host, Kuban Cossack Host, and other Cossack hosts. The Ussuri Cossack Host headquarters was first located in Vladivostok and then in Iman (now Dalnerechensk). Its nakazny ataman (who was also the military governor of the region) subordinated to the Governor General of the Amur region, who, in turn, was the nakazny ataman of the Amur and the Ussuri Cossack Hosts.

title: Invention of Matryoshka doll (“Babushka” doll)
description: The first Russian nested doll set was made in 1890 by wood turning craftsman and wood carver Vasily Zvyozdochkin. Traditionally the outer layer is a woman, dressed in a sarafan, a long and shapeless traditional Russian peasant jumper dress. The figures inside may be of any gender; the smallest, innermost doll is typically a baby turned from a single piece of wood. Much of the artistry is in the painting of each doll, which can be very elaborate. The dolls often follow a theme; the themes may vary, from fairy tale characters to Soviet leaders. In some countries, matryoshka dolls are often referred to as babushka dolls, though they are not known by this name in Russian; babushka (бабушка) means "grandmother" or "old woman".

title: Construction of Trans-Siberian Railway begins
description: The Trans-Siberian Railway connects European Russia to the Russian Far East. Spanning a length of over 9,289 kilometers (5,772 miles), it is the longest railway line in the world. It runs from the city of Moscow in the west to the city of Vladivostok in the east. During the period of the Russian Empire, government ministers—personally appointed by Alexander III and his son Nicholas II—supervised the building of the railway network between 1891 and 1916. Even before its completion, the line attracted travelers who documented their experiences. Since 1916, the Trans-Siberian Railway has directly connected Moscow with Vladivostok.

title: Alexander III’s Statute on cities’ self-governance
description: The new statute of 1892 did further narrowed the circle of voters by introducing a property qualification and increased administrative control over the activities of urban self-government bodies, effectively countering Alexander II’s statute of 1870.

title: Law on the Restriction of Land Redistributions in the Peasant Commune
description: The 1893 regulations restricted peasants' rights to general land redistributions (not more frequently than every 12 years), and private land redistributions were prohibited. Land redistributions came under the control of zemstvo district administrators. Peasants continued to engage in land redistribution in defiance of the law. In the early 20th century, communal land redistributions became less frequent.

title: Reign of Nicholas II begins
description: Nicholas II was the last Emperor of Russia, King of Poland and Grand Duke of Finland, ruling from 1 November 1894 until his abdication on 15 March 1917. During his reign, Nicholas gave support to the economic and political reforms promoted by his prime ministers, Sergei Witte and Pyotr Stolypin. He advocated modernization based on foreign loans and close ties with France, but resisted giving the new parliament (the Duma) major roles. Ultimately, progress was undermined by Nicholas's commitment to autocratic rule, strong aristocratic opposition and defeats sustained by the Russian military in the Russo-Japanese War and World War I.

title: Monetary reform
description: As a result of the Monetary reform of 1895, Russia switched to the gold standard. The State Bank received the right to issue credit notes, exchangeable for gold without restrictions. Gold coins were put into circulation in denominations from 5 to 15 rubles. The reform strengthened the ruble exchange rate and improved the investment climate in the country.

title: Khodynka Tragedy
description: The Khodynka Tragedy was a crowd crush that occurred in May 1896, on Khodynka Field in Moscow, Russia. The crush happened during the festivities after the coronation of the last Emperor of Russia, Nicholas II. While 1,282 corpses were collected from the scene, injury estimates range widely from 1,200 to 20,000.

title: 1st Russian Empire Census
description: The first general census of the population of the Russian Empire in 1897 was the first and only nation-wide census performed in the Russian Empire (excluding the Grand Duchy of Finland). It recorded demographic data as of 28 January 1897. The total population of the Russian Empire was recorded to be 125,640,021 people, 62,477,348 or 49.73% of whom were men and 63,162,673 or 50.27% were women—the median age was 21.16 years.

title: 1st Congress of the RSDLP (Lenin’s Party)
description: The Russian Social Democratic Labour Party was a socialist political party founded in 1898 in Minsk. Formed to unite the various revolutionary organizations of the Russian Empire into one party, the RSDLP split in 1903 into Bolsheviks ("majority") and Mensheviks ("minority") factions, with the Bolshevik faction eventually becoming the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.

title: Hague Convention of 1899
description: The Hague Convention of 1899 was a series of international treaties and declarations negotiated at an international peace conference at The Hague in the Netherlands. It was among the first formal statements of the laws of war and war crimes in the body of secular international law. The First Hague Conference came from a proposal on 24 August 1898 by Russian Tsar Nicholas II.[8] Nicholas and Count Mikhail Nikolayevich Muravyov, his foreign minister, were instrumental in initiating the conference. The conference opened on 18 May 1899, the Tsar's birthday. The treaties, declarations, and final act of the conference were signed on 29 July of that year, and they entered into force on 4 September 1900.

title: The Russian invasion of Manchuria
description: The Russian invasion of Manchuria in 1900 refers to the military campaign launched by the Russian Empire during the Boxer Rebellion. As part of the Eight-Nation Alliance, Russia sent troops to Manchuria to suppress the Boxer uprising and protect its interests in the region. The Russian forces, along with troops from other countries, successfully occupied several strategic locations in Manchuria, including the city of Harbin. The invasion marked a significant expansion of Russian influence in Northeast Asia and contributed to the subsequent events leading to the Russo-Japanese War.
